Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Improving scientific innovation by linking funding and scholarly literature

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project identifies scientists and organizations and their topical interests, enabling the tracking of past productivity and impact. By linking scholarly literature and grants, this project creates a unified dataset that captures diverse scientific disciplines and federal grant award types. A web-based levels the playing field for scientists lacking knowledge about research and funding programs. Users are expected to spend less time searching the literature and more time evaluating significance and impact.

This project consolidates disparate repositories of publications and grants, disambiguates and enriches information about scientists and organizations, and builds a web-based tool to help navigate this information. This project solves many of these issues by modeling the relationship approximately 2.6 million grants from the Federal RePORTER, and a consolidated, multi-source dataset of millions of articles from Microsoft Academic Graph (83 M), MEDLINE (25 M), PubMed Open Access Subset (1 M), ArXiv (0.6 M), and the National Bureau of Economic Research [NBER] (14K). The project creates a web-based tool that generates instantaneous reports about publications, grants, scientists, and organizations related to users' interests. The unified dataset and web tool could revolutionize how Program Officers evaluate proposals and how researchers find fundable ideas, making science faster, more accurate, and less biased.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the first steps when starting scientific or technological advances is discovering what was done before by others. This process has generally been done manually by looking at countless data sources with conflicting information. Similarly, when funding agencies, such as NSF, need to decide whom to give funding to, they need to assess the degree to which the proposal in front of them is sufficiently novel. Again, this novelty assessment is done by hand. Recent releases of large datasets about past publications, funding, and institutional affiliation of scientists open the door to automating many of these manual processes still present in science. In this project, we have developed such system and made it easily accessible through a website https://eileen.io

The website that we have developed is freely available to anybody. The website ingests publications, grants, and information about scientists from Pubmed, Arxiv, Medline, and the Federal Exporter datasets. It blends all these datasets and offers an easy-to-use interface to the users. The users can search these documents and get recommendations about the results. For example, once scientists have found a publication or grant of interest, the system recommends similar publications and grants. The user then can quickly and effortlessly assess the novelty, state of the art, and previous funding of an idea.

Additionally, we make available all the code and the datasets on the website https://github.com/sciosci/nsf_data_ingestion. We will continue updating this data for the foreseeable future.
